title: Portfolio management
body: Portfolio management is the core of FA system. Here is what you can do:

title: Portfolio management
body: Store up-to-date information securities and market prices. FA system lets you handle a wide range of securities, such as equities, funds, bonds, options, future contracts, and any security types you need. To keep securities and market prices up-to-date, you can use one of FA's standard integrations.

title: Portfolio management
body: Manage client contacts. You can onboard your new clients, check and update the client information using FA's standard integrations.

title: Portfolio management
body: View portfolio positions. FA system provides detailed information for each portfolio position, including market values, purchase prices, exposure, accrued interest, and so on. Portfolio positions are calculated based on transactions, using the valuation method you chose for a portfolio.

title: Portfolio management
body: Keep track of account balances and provide credit to your clients. Similar to portfolio positions, account balance is calculated based on transactions. You can also keep track of the interest accrued on your accounts.

title: Portfolio management
body: Align portfolio holdings with investment objectives. FA system provides various tools for forming a portfolio and keeping it in line with your investment objectives. You can set up a strategy, model portfolio or investment plan and use them to rebalance your portfolios.

title: Portfolio management
body: Create trade orders and record transactions. Trade orders created in FA system are sent to external systems for execution. When the trade is completed, FA system creates transactions and updates portfolio positions.

title: Portfolio management
body: Run corporate actions to multiple customer portfolios at once.

title: Position calculation
body: FA system calculates portfolio positions based on transactions. When you save a transaction, position data is updated and report data recalculation is triggered. For more information about portfolio report recalculation, see Report data calculation in FA Admin guide.

title: Redemption
body: The redemption corporate action allows you to mass-create principal repayments and expirations for bonds. Expirations are generated based on the maturity date and price specified for the bond in the Security window, Extra info tab. Partial redemptions use the redemption schedule and amounts specified in the Security window, Extra info tab, Redemptions subtab. Before creating this corporate action, make sure you have this bond information filled in.

title: Redemption
body: To record the redemption corporate action, click New → Corporate action in the top menu and fill in the fields (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Redemption
body: Security*

title: Redemption
body: The bond security for which you need to create expiration or partial redemption transactions.

title: Redemption
body: Currency

title: Redemption
body: The currency of expiration or partial redemption. By default the redemption currency is the security’s currency. If you specify a different currency, the redemption is calculated in the specified currency and converted to the security currency.

title: Redemption
body: Redemption %

title: Redemption
body: Redemption as a share of principal. You can fetch the redemption %, redemption date and settlement date from the bond information defined in the Security window. To do this, fill in the Security and Groups, contacts, portfolios fields and enter "?" in the Redemption % field.

title: Redemption
body: Redemption price per share

title: Redemption
body: The price at which a bond unit is redeemed. The default is 100 (issue price). You can adjust this value if needed.

title: Redemption
body: Redemption date

title: Redemption
body: Transaction date of the transaction created. You can fetch the redemption date together with settlement date and redemption % from the bond information defined in the Security window. To do this, fill in the Security and Groups, contacts, portfolios fields and enter "?" in the Redemption % field.

title: Redemption
body: Settlement date

title: Redemption
body: Settlement date of the transaction created. You can fetch the settlement date together with redemption date and redemption % from the bond information defined in the Security window. To do this, fill in the Security and Groups, contacts, portfolios fields and enter "?" in the Redemption % field.

title: Redemption
body: Trasanction type

title: Redemption
body: Transaction type. For expirations, choose "Expire (EXP)". For partial redemptions, choose "Paydown (PD).

title: Redemption
body: A new corporate action is created with the Save and close button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to create transactions to your portfolios.

title: Securities and market prices
body: The FA Platform allows you to record operations with different kinds of securities such as equities, bonds, or fund units as well as derivatives and FX contracts. To work with bonds, see Bonds. To work with complex securities like derivatives and FX contracts in FA, see Derivatives and FX contracts. For a list of security types in FA, see Standard security types.

title: Securities and market prices
body: You can create new securities or update existing ones in the Security window. See Security window in FA Back reference for details on adding information for securities. You can also search for and view securities saved in the system in the Securities view (see Securities view in FA Back reference).

title: Securities and market prices
body: You can also import securities in files or from a market data provider. To fetch security information from market data providers, see Get security data and Get extended security data. For importing securities in files, see File formats for importing securities and security prices in FA Back reference.

title: Securities and market prices
body: Security market prices can also be entered manually, fetched from a market data provider, or imported in files (see Manage market prices).

title: Securities and market prices
body: You can track and analyze security indicators such as duration, modified duration, convexity, and YTM for securities. For this, you need to define the key figures. See Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities for more information.

title: Securities and market prices
body: To read about security configurations in the system, see Security preferences.

title: FX contracts
body: FX contract is a contract to exchange one currency to another at a specified date at an FX rate that is fixed on the purchase date. FA system lets you handle the following contract types:

title: FX contracts
body: FX Spot. With FX Spots, cashflow transactions for the specified date are created automatically in the portfolio. On the contract date, the system processes the exchange by depositing and withdrawing cash to and from the accounts.

title: FX contracts
body: FX Forward. With FX forwards, cashflow transactions for the specified date are created automatically in the portfolio. During the contract period, you can track forward cashflows that are valuated based on yield curves. On the contract date, the system processes the exchange by depositing and withdrawing cash to and from the accounts.

title: FX contracts
body: FX Swap. With FX Swaps, cashflow transactions for the near leg and far leg are created automatically in the portfolio. During the contract period, you can track forward cashflows that are valuated based on yield curves. On the contract dates, the system processes the exchange by depositing and withdrawing cash to and from the accounts.

title: Handle FX contracts
body: You can add FX contracts to portfolios to change currency between accounts. If a contract induces forward cashflows (FX Forward or FX Spot), you can track the discounted present values of the cashflows during the contract period. On the end date, the system automatically makes cash transfers.

title: Create an FX contract
body: Create an FX contract

title: Create an FX contract
body: To create an FX contract in FA Back:

title: Create an FX contract
body: In the top menu, go to New → New contract. The Contract window opens.

title: Create an FX contract
body: Fill in the fields. For the filed descriptions, see Contract window in FA Back reference. Click Save.

title: Create an FX contract
body: The system creates the contract, forward cashflow positions, and contract cashflow transactions for the end of the contract. You can view and track the contract and cashflows in the Overview:

title: Create an FX contract
body: For the FX Forward and FX Swap contracts, the upper section shows Forward cashflow positions that result from the contract. You can track the discounted market value of each cashflow.

title: Create an FX contract
body: The lower section shows transactions related to the contract:

title: Create an FX contract
body: Add Contract transaction that lets you access the contract information you entered. It doesn't have any transaction effects.

title: Create an FX contract
body: Forward cashflow transactions (for FX Forward and FX Swap contracts) that open forward cashflow positions in the portfolio. Depending on the contract preferences, forward cashflow transactions can be hidden from the Overview.

title: Create an FX contract
body: Cashflow in/out transactions to process the exchange on the contract date. For FX Spots and FX Forwards, you get two cashflows at the end of the contract. FA Swaps produce two cashflows in the beginning and two cashflows at the end of the contract.

title: View contract information
body: To view the contract you created:

title: View contract information
body: Find the Add Contract transaction in the Overview or in the Transactions view. The Add Contract transaction:

title: View contract information
body: Doesn't have any transaction effects. The amount is specified as 1, and other numeric values available as columns are shown as 0.

title: View contract information
body: Is linked to the contract security that is created automatically. You can see the contract security name that indicates the contract type, date, cashflows, and FX rate. For example, FX FWD #36 2019-05-02: USD +10000.00 / EUR -8901.55 (1.123).

title: View contract information
body: Double-click the transaction row to open the Contract window and view the contract details.

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: If a contract involves forward cashflows, you can see them as portfolio positions in the Overview. The position row shows:

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: The contract value, at the rate agreed in the contract:

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: In the cashflow currency ( Amount filed)

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: In the portfolio currency (Purchase value field)

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: The discounted present value in the Market value field. Forward cashflow positions are revaluated daily using yield curves. The system calculates the discounted present value of each forward cashflow with the yield curves defined in the system, and uses these discount factors to calculate each day’s market value of your forward cashflow positions.

title: Analyze currency exposure
body: You can see the currency exposure of the portfolio investments in Analytics+. To do this, group the analysis by currency.

title: Close a contract
body: On the contract date, the system transfers the cash between accounts and closes forward cashflow positions.

title: Modify a contract
body: To modify any contract information, edit the contract in the Contract window securities and transactions are updated accordingly..

title: Modify a contract
body: Click the Add contract transaction in the Overview.

title: Modify a contract
body: Edit the contract details in the Contract window that opens and save the changes.

title: Modify a contract
body: Once you save the changes, the system updates:

title: Modify a contract
body: Contract security, including the security name. All categorizations or allocations you added remain untouched.

title: Modify a contract
body: Forward cashflow securities. If the previously used forward cashflow securities are in use in another portfolio, they are left untouched, or if not used, deleted from the system.

title: Modify a contract
body: Forward cashflow transactions: Counter, Counter portfolio, Market place, Settlement place, Description on statement and Internal info fields are filled in based on the contract details.

title: Modify a contract
body: Forward cashflow positions (portfolio report data is recalculated).

title: Modify a contract
body: Contract cashflows.

title: Deleting a contract
body: To delete your contract:

title: Deleting a contract
body: Click the Add contract transaction in the Overview.

title: Deleting a contract
body: Click in the Contract window that opens.

title: Deleting a contract
body: When you delete the contract, the system deletes all linked securities, transactions and positions and recalculates portfolio report data.

title: Deleting a contract
body: Do not try to delete contract securities and transactions - delete the contract itself to ensure everything gets deleted correctly.

title: Valuation of forward cashflows
body: For valuating forward cashflows, the system calculates the discounted present value of each forward cashflow using yield curves defined in the system. Valuating forward cashflows is a relevant part of managing FX contracts' forward cashflows, but also allows you to manage other forward cashflows, such as Certificates of deposits.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: To valuate forward cashflows, make sure you have appropriate forward cashflow securities in the system. The forward cashflow securities represent a forward cashflow on a given currency on a given date, and you can reuse the forward cashflow securities on the same currency and date.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: For FX Contracts, forward cashflow securities are created automatically when saving a contract. If you want to manage other forward cashflows, you can create forward cashflow securities with the following information:

title: Basic info
body: Status

title: Basic info
body: Status should be set to Active. Valuation is automatically done only on active securities.

title: Basic info
body: Type

title: Basic info
body: Type should use the base type DISCOUNT. Valuation is done only on securities with the base type discount.

title: Basic info
body: Currency

title: Basic info
body: Currency should be set based on the currency of the forward cashflow. Currency is used to find the appropriate discount yield curve from the curve group linking the currency to a curve.

title: Extra info
body: Maturity date

title: Extra info
body: Maturity date should be set as the the maturity date of the forward cashflow. Maturity date is used when calculating the discount factors on the forward cashflow - discount factors are calculated up until the maturity date, and at the maturity date, the discount factor corresponds with the maturity price.

title: Extra info
body: Maturity price

title: Extra info
body: Maturity price should be set to 1. Maturity price is used when calculating the discount factors on the forward cashflows - on the maturity date, the discount factor corresponds with the maturity price.

title: Calculating discount factors based on yield curves
body: The system calculates discounted present value of forward cashflows based on:

title: Calculating discount factors based on yield curves
body: Yield curve that provides interest rates (yields) for different maturities.

title: Calculating discount factors based on yield curves
body: Discount factors that indicate how to valuate a forward cashflow on a given date. The discount factors are stored in the forward cashflow security's Market data info tab, Close 5 field. Discount factors are calculated from the beginning of the first position in the security (when the forward cashflow position is opened with the first transaction) until the maturity date of your forward cashflow security, defined in the Extra info tab. On the maturity date, the discount factor equals to the maturity price defined for your forward cashflow security.

title: Calculating discount factors based on yield curves
body: The discount factors can directly be used to valuate the forward cashflow: amount * discount factor = market value.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: After you have set up your forward cashflow securities correctly and have defined yield curves for all the currencies you want to valuate forward cashflows for, the system provides you with tools for automatic and manual valuation of your forward cashflow securities. Valuation is always done for all appropriate securities regardless of their status.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: To keep your forward cashflows up-to-date, the automatic nightly report update valuates all your forward cashflows with new discount factors based on latest yield curve prices. The system automatically valuates your forward cashflows in the following situations:

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: When saving / modifying a contract that induces forward cashflows. Discount factors are automatically calculated from the beginning of the forward cashflow (i.e. usually from the beginning of the contract) until yesterday (or maturity date, if that is in the past). If the forward cashflow security already exists, only missing discount factors are calculated for the past in case the new contract starts earlier than discount factors currently exist.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: During the nightly report data update. Discount factors are automatically calculated daily during the nightly report data update, ensuring you get a new discount factor on your forward cashflows with the latest yield curve prices.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: If you are connected to a market data connector to fetch latest end-of-day prices automatically at night, the discount factors are calculated after the new market data observations have been fetched from the connector. Discount factors are calculated for as many days as you get prices for, i.e. as configures in Number of days market prices are fetched for in the nightly run in Market data connector Preferences. Existing discount factors are updated in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: If you are not connected to a market data connector, the discount factors are calculated as Valuate missing valuations for all securities.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: When fetching market data from a market data connector through the Update menu. Discount factors are automatically calculated every time you fetch new market data observations through the menu - this will fetch new prices for you interest rates involved in your yield curves, thus discount factors are recalculated with the new prices. Discount factors are calculated for the same time period you selected to fetch prices for (e.g. 7 days), and Get missing market prices will Valuate missing valuations for all securities. Existing discount factors are updated in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: In addition, you can manually revaluate your forward cashflow securities through the Security window or Update menu if the appropriate permission to revaluate securities has been enabled for your user role. You can manually valuate your forward cashflows in the following situations:

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate close 5 button in the Security window's Market data info tab is available for securities with base type DISCOUNT and other relevant information. Clicking the button will calculate discount factors

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Since the latest existing observation until yesterday or until maturity date, if that is in the past (i.e. since the latest discount factor you can see in the close 5 field until the day you can expect to have close prices for your yield curve interest rates).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: If your forward cashflow security doesn't yet have any discount factors, since the beginning of the first position in the security (i.e. when the forward cashflow position is opened with the first transaction) until yesterday or until maturity date, if that is in the past. If you create a forward cashflow security and don't yet have a position on it in a portfolio, discount factors are not calculated.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: If you want to revaluate the entire history of your forward cashflow, first Delete Close 5 prices and then Revaluate close 5.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities menu items in the Update menu allow you to recalculate the discount factors for a specific time period on all your securities with the base type DISCOUNT and other relevant information. Discount factors on a security are never calculated before the beginning of the position or after the maturity date, and all calculations are done until yesterday. Revaluating securities will always trigger a report recalculation to update the effect of the new values to your portfolios - report recalculation will affect all portfolios that contain the securities that receive a new valuation. Options available in the menu are:

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities for past 7 days - recalculates the discount factors for past 7 days, updating the existing discount factors in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities for past 30 days - recalculates the discount factors for past 30 days, updating the existing discount factors in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities for past 365 days - recalculates the discount factors for past 365 days, updating the existing discount factors in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities from [date] - recalculates the discount factors from the shown date (configured Earliest market price date in Market data connector Preferences) onward, updating the existing discount factors in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Valuate missing valuations for all securities - recalculates the discount factors since the latest existing observation for each security. This option goes through all relevant securities one-by-one, determines per each security the latest available discount factor, and recalculates discount factors for that security from that date onward. If your forward cashflow security doesn't yet have any discount factors, discount factors are calculated since the beginning of the first position in the security. Depending on the history, your discount might be calculated for different time periods for different securities, depending what their latest available observation is - this option allows you to calculate "valuations that are newer than the newest observation already stored".

title: Securities, transactions and positions related to FX contract
body: The diagram shows the structure of securities, transactions and positions created by the system to process the contract:

title: Securities, transactions and positions related to FX contract

body: Securities and transactions marked with the dotted line are not seen in the Overview and aren't needed for regular contract handling. They are used by the system to store and manage the data. Making changes in these securities and transactions is not recommended – instead, you should edit the contract you created.

body: FX FWD #[security external ID] [date yyyy-MM-dd]: [first cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [first cashflow's Amount] / [second cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [second cashflow's Amount] ([FX rate])

title: Contract security
body: FX SWAP [near leg date yyyy-MM-dd]: [near leg first cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [near leg first cashflow's Amount] / [near leg second cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [near leg second cashflow's Amount] ([near leg FX rate]) / [far leg date yyyy-MM-dd]: [far leg first cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [far leg first cashflow's Amount] / [far leg second cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [far leg second cashflow's Amount] ([far leg FX rate])

title: Contract security

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Forward cashflow securities are created if the contract induces forward cashflows. A forward cashflow security is a combination of a cashflow, currency and a maturity date, for example "1000 USD bought on 2024-08-08".

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: You can find forward cashflow securities in the Securities view.

title: Forward cashflow securities

It includes contract type, maturity date of the forward cashflow, currency code of the forward cashflow currency and value of the cashflow with the syntax TYPE #EXTERNAL_ID yyyy-MM-dd CURRENCY +/- cashflow (e.g. FX FWD #34 2019-11-29 EUR -9.1k). The date depends on your selection in contract preferences (transaction date or settlement date).

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: The cashflow amount is shortened to the number of thousands (K), millions (M), billions (B) or trillions (T). No rounding is applied.

This allows the system to track which forward cashflows are generated based on which contract, and for example to show the contract in the transaction listing on the Overview when clicking a forward cashflow position. You cannot edit your forward cashflows' linked security afterwards.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Maturity date (Extra info tab)

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Maturity date of the forward cashflow ( set to transaction date or settlement date, depending on contract preferences). Maturity date is used when calculating the discount factors on the forward cashflows - discount factors are calculated only up until the maturity date, and at the maturity date, the discount factor corresponds to the maturity price.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Maturity price (Extra info tab)

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Maturity price is set to 1. Maturity price is used when calculating the discount factors on the forward cashflows - on the maturity date, the discount factor corresponds to the maturity price.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Market data info tab

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Market data info tab contains the daily discount factors in the Close 5 field, calculated for the forward cashflow security from the beginning of the contract (i.e. the contract date) up until the maturity date of the forward cashflow security. The system calculates the discount factors with yield curves, and the discount factors are used to valuate the forward cashflow positions in your portfolios.

title: Forward cashflow transactions
body: Forward cashflow transactions are created if the contract induces forward cashflows. You can find these transactions in the Overview or in the Transactions view. Forward cashflow transactions have no cash effect. They create future cashflow positions in the portfolio.

title: Forward cashflow transactions
body: Forward cashflow transactions are regenerated if a contract is modified – old transactions are deleted, and new ones are created. Any manual changes to the cash flow transactions are lost.

title: Forward cashflow transactions
body: Counter, Counter portfolio, Market place, Settlement place, Description, Internal info and Tags are filled in based on the information you filled in on the contract. This ensures the transactions generated based on your contracts are categorized consistently, allowing you for example to search and report them.

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: When you save a contract, the system recalculates the portfolio's reporting data to show the forward cashflow positions for both legs of the contract, opened with the forward cashflow transactions. The forward cashflow positions are open from the start of the contract until the cashflowscashflows take effect at the end of the contract.

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: You'll get one positive and one negative forward cashflow position. The Market value of the forward cashflow position tells you the discounted present value of the forward cashflow on the selected date. The system calculates the discounted present value of each forward cashflow with the yield curves defined in the system (see Preference - Yield curves).

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: Forward cashflows are valuated automatically during nightly report update based on latest yield curve prices. In addition, you can manually revaluate your forward cashflow securities in the Market data info tab in the -security window or Top menu.

title: Loans as bonds
body: Loans are used to borrow money for investment purposes. A loan with regular interest payments is set up in FA Back as a bond. You can track accrued interest, calculate interest payments, and handle loan repayment.

title: Create a loan security
body: Maturity price – "1".

title: Create a loan security
body: Calendar (day count convention) – The agreed day counting convention.

title: Create a loan security
body: Frequency – "Once".

title: Create a loan security
body: Fixings for floating rate note – Start date and agreed loan rate.

title: Create a loan security
body: You can have multiple coupon periods both with a fixed or floating rate. The security configuration in the Extra info tab is the same as for a bond.

title: Add a loan to a portfolio
body: Add a loan to a portfolio

title: Add a loan to a portfolio
body: To add a loan to a portfolio, use a sell transaction. Enter an ID from another system or your counterparty in the Reference field and choose the counterparty in the Counterparty field.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: Create interest payments and expirations

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: Interest payments and maturity processing are handled in the same way as for bonds. To generate coupon payments and expirations, create and run a corporate action. An important note: use the "Expire short position (EXPSH)" transaction type.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: To create and run a corporate action, use one of the tools that suits you best:

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For a coupon payment on one bond, follow the steps in Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For coupon payments on multiple bonds, import corporate actions in a file (see File format for importing corporate actions) and run them from the Corporate actions view in FA Back (see Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios).

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For coupon payments and expirations on all bonds in the system, use the functionality described in Automate corporate actions.

title: Amortized bonds
body: Amortized bonds have principal repayments over the life period of the bond, along with periodic interest payments. For each period, the bond pays part of the principal and an interest amount calculated based on the outstanding principal. You can define you own repayment plan for the bond or choose one of the following options:

title: Amortized bonds
body: Equated instalments – Create payments in equal amounts that include principal and interest. The principal amount gradually increases with time.

title: Amortized bonds
body: Straight line – Create payments that include principal and interest. The principal part is the same in each payment. The payment amount decreases over time.

title: Amortized bonds
body: Other – Specify schedule and repayment amounts yourself.

title: Amortized bonds
body: To generate the principal payout transactions in the portfolios that own the bond, use the redemption corporate action (see the instruction below).

title: Amortized bonds
body: When trading amortizing bonds, the trade amount can be based on the outstanding principal or original principal (you can define this in the bond information). The interest and principal accrued over the current period are added to the trade amount and paid to the bond seller.

title: Create an amortized bond
body: To create an amortized bond:

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Choose New → New security in the top menu. The Security window opens.

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Fill in the necessary fields. The following fields are specific for bonds, and specifically for amotrizing bonds:

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Basic info tab:

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Set "Bond" type.

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Note that bonds are usually valued as a percentage of par. You can make this work in FA system by entering "100" in both Multiplier fields.

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Extra info tab: define the coupon payment settings

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Dates and prices at the top.

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Fixings information in the Fixings subtab. For a fixed rate bond, enter the calendar, frequency and fixing values. For a floating rate bond, enter floating rate per fixing date.

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Index information for index-linked bonds in the Index calc. method subtab.

title: Create an amortized bond
body: Redemption information in the Redemptions subtab. To calculate redemptions automatically, fill in the frequency, first date and redemption plan and click Generate redemptions.

title: Create an amortized bond
body: For the full list of fields in the Security window, see Security window in FA Back reference.

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: Amortized bonds are sold at a price that includes the interest and principal repayment accrued for the period up to settlement date.

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: Amortized bonds can be quoted as a percentage of the outstanding principal or a percentage of the original principal. Here are the examples:

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: Price as a percentage of the outstanding principal. If the outstanding principal is €500 and the bond is quoted at 102, this means the bond is traded at €510 (102% of €500).

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: Price as a percentage of the original principal. If the original principal is €1000 and the bond is quoted at 98,5, this means the bond is traded at €985 (98.5% of €1000), regardless of the current outstanding principal.

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: The preferred way of trading a bond is chosen per bond security in the Security window, Extra info tab, Redemptions subtab.

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: To buy or sell amortizing bonds, create a transaction and fill in the transaction details:

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: Define the transaction date and settlement date.

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: Fill in the bond's principal amounts:

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: To fetch the original or outstanding principal amount in the Denomination field (depending on the market price base for the bond security), type "?".

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: Fill in the original principal amount in the Principal field. Original principal amount is used to calculate partial redemptions for the acquired bond.

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: To fetch accrued coupon interest, type "?" in the Accrued interest field.

title: Buy and sell amortized bonds
body: You can use deferral of the bond purchase price to split the payment in several transactions. For details, see Run deferrals.

title: Track accrued interest on amortized bonds
body: The system calculates the interest accrued from the last payment date of the bond. You can check the accrued interest:

title: Track accrued interest on amortized bonds
body: In the Overview and Analytics+, Accr.int column.

title: Track accrued interest on amortized bonds
body: In the Positions view, Accr.int column.

title: Track accrued interest on amortized bonds
body: Note that the accrued interest between the transaction and settlement date is fetched from the transaction.

title: View the original principal
body: You can see the original principal amount in the position in formation in the Principal column in the Overview and Analytics+.

title: Create coupon payments and expirations
body: To generate coupon payments and expirations, create and run a corporate action. You can schedule corporate action runs to repeat them regularly. Use one of the tools that suits you best:

title: Create coupon payments and expirations
body: For a coupon payment on one bond, follow the steps in Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios.

title: Create coupon payments and expirations
body: For coupon payments on multiple bonds, import corporate actions in a file (see File format for importing corporate actions) and run them from the Corporate actions view in FA Back (see Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios).

title: Create coupon payments and expirations
body: For coupon payments and expirations on all bonds in the system, use the functionality described in Automate corporate actions.

title: Create coupon payments and expirations
body: You can use deferral of accrued interest to postpone the payment. For details, see [Extension] Bookkeeping - Deferrals

title: Create partial redemptions
body: To generate redemption payments, create and run corporate action.

title: Create partial redemptions
body: For creating partial redemptions on one bond, follow the steps in Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios and see the corporate action details in Redemption. The redemption corporate action is generated using the original principal you specified in the buy transaction and the redemption plan you specified for the bond.

title: Create partial redemptions
body: For creating partial redemptions on multiple bonds, you can import corporate actions in a file (see File format for importing corporate actions).

title: Monitor key bond indicators
body: Convexity and duration for bonds are shown as columns in the Securities view.

title: Monitor key bond indicators
body: You can monitor and aggregate key bond indicators, such as yield, convexity, and duration, in Analytics+. For details, see Analytics+ in FA Back reference and Monitor portfolios with debt instruments in Analytics+.

title: Transactions
body: Transactions are used to handle and register operations with securities and cash, such as buying and selling assets, or depositing cash. Portfolio positions and cash amounts are calculated based on transactions. Once a transaction is accepted, portfolio positions and cash amounts are recalculated. You can create transactions directly (see Add transactions) or generate them based on trade orders (see Trade order execution). If you use FA accounting, bookkeeping entries are created based on transactions.

title: Transactions
body: The FA Platform has a set of transaction types for cash and security transactions (see Transaction types for cash transactions and Transaction types for security transactions). The transaction types are specific to security types (for example: coupon payments are specific to debt instruments). Some transaction types are shared between several security types (for example: buying and selling are available for several security types).

title: Transactions
body: Each transaction type has certain effects on the portfolio. For example, the cash effect of a buy transaction is to reduce the cash balance of the transaction account, and the cash effect of a sell transaction is to add to the cash balance of the transaction account. For more information about transaction effects, see Preference - Transactions in FA Back reference.

title: Transactions
body: A transaction includes costs, fees, and taxes which you specify either as a percentage or an amount (see Portfolio window and Portfolios view in FA Back reference). The effects defined for the transaction type determine if the costs, fees, and taxes are added to the transaction amount or subtracted from it. You can also extract the costs and taxes into separate transactions, for example, to keep track of costs in a separate portfolio (see Extract costs and taxes as separate transactions).

title: Transactions
body: You can also import transactions in files (see File formats for importing transactions and trade orders in FA Back reference).

title: Transaction types
body: In the FA Platform, each security type has a set of transaction types you can use. For a list of transaction types available by default, see Transaction types for security transactions and Transaction types for cash transactions.

title: Transaction types
body: Modifying transaction types is not recommended. Transaction types are defined to work in specific scenarios and changes can cause, for example, incorrect performance calculations. Instead of editing the transaction types, you can rename them or add new ones.

title: Transaction types
body: If you want to modify the name of an existing transaction type, you can use the Translate button in Transaction types (Preference, Transactions section). You should not modify the transaction type name directly.

title: Add a transaction type
body: You can add a new transaction type if the standard types do not include a suitable type for your needs. Use a similar existing type as an example. If you need to create a transaction type from scratch, contact FA support to ensure that no problems occur, for example, with profit calculations.

title: Add a transaction type
body: To add a new transaction type, do the following:

title: Add a transaction type
body: Open Transaction types (Preference, Transactions section) and click Add transaction type.

title: Add a transaction type
body: Fill in the fields and make sure all effects are correct (see Preference - Transactions in FA Back reference).

title: Add a transaction type
body: Click Save.

title: Questions about transaction types
body: I get several different cost and profit transactions from my custody. I want to record all of them in FA. Can I add a transaction type for this?

title: Questions about transaction types
body: Yes, you can add a new transaction type for this. Copy the transaction type effects from a similar standard transaction type and link the new transaction type to the necessary security types.

title: Add transactions
body: You can create transactions from scratch or based on a portfolio position, for example, to sell or buy a security already in your portfolio. Creating transactions from portfolio positions is useful for coupons, dividends, and sell-all situations. You can also create transactions based on a position in multiple portfolios for partial redemptions or security switches.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: To create a transaction from scratch, do the following:

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: In the Overview, select the portfolio in which you want to add a transaction. If you select the portfolio first, the transaction is directly linked to the correct portfolio.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Click New transaction in the New menu (top left) and select a security type.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Fill in the fields in the Transaction window. For descriptions of the fields, see Transaction window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Save the transaction.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: To create a new transaction based on the position in the selected portfolio, do the following:

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: In the Overview, right-click the position row and select New.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Select Transaction with position’s security and amount where portfolio, security and amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date, or Transaction with position’s security, amount and trade amount where portfolio, security, amount, unit price, costs/taxes and trade amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Fill in the fields. For descriptions of the fields, see Transaction window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Save the transaction.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: You can create transactions based on a position in multiple portfolios, for example, to do partial redemptions or switches from one security to another using the reinvest option.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: To create transactions based on the position in multiple portfolios, do the following:

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: In the Positions view, search for a position to use as a starting point.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Click Create transactions and fill in the fields in the Generate transactions from positions window:

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Create: The type of object to create. Select "Transactions".

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction type: The transaction type to use. The list of available types depends on the selected security.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Amount: The amount as percentage of the original position size.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Unit price: The unit price to use in the transactions. Enter a question mark to have the system automatically fill in the latest available price.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction date: The date when the transactions take effect.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Settlement date: The settlement date of the transactions.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Tags: The tags for the transactions.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: If the selected transaction type has a positive cash effect, reinvest by clicking Add security and filling in the fields, including the security to reinvest in. You can reinvest into multiple securities.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Click Preview transactions to check the transactions to be created. You can uncheck transactions you do not want the system to create.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: Click Confirm.

title: Related links
body: Transaction window in FA Back reference

title: Related links
body: Transactions view in FA Back reference

title: Reconciliation
body: The reconciliation feature allows you to:

title: Reconciliation
body: Compare account balances and position data from an external source (for example, your custodian or a bank) with the data in the FA system to identify the mismatches.

title: Reconciliation
body: You should perform reconciliation in FA Operations rather than in FA Back. FA Operations is a newer app that is gradually replacing FA Back for operations-related tasks. For reconciliation instructions in FA Operations, see Reconciliation.

title: Reconciliation
body: Export positions from FA to reconcile or update data in another FA instance, or in a third-party system. For instructions, see Export FA data for reconciliation.

title: Related links
body: M2 Wealth in FA User guide

title: Related links
body: Reconciliation and FA Operations in FA Product Description

title: Related links
body: FA Operations

title: Reconcile positions and cash in FA Back
body: The reconciliation flow in the FA Back includes the following stages:

title: Reconcile positions and cash in FA Back
body: Obtain position or cash balance data from the bank or custodian.

title: Reconcile positions and cash in FA Back
body: Fetch the obtained reconciliation data in FA Back: upload the file or transfer it to the FA system automatically: see Fetch reconciliation data in FA Back.

title: Reconcile positions and cash in FA Back
body: Set up FA Back to skip extra positions in FA Platform, if needed: see Handle positions missing in the data source.

title: Reconcile positions and cash in FA Back
body: View positions and correct mismatches: see View positions and correct mismatches

title: Fetch reconciliation data in FA Back
body: Depending on the custodian and the data format they provide, you can choose one of the following options to fetch the data to PA Platform:

title: Use bank or custody connection
body: You can fetch reconciliation data using FA standard integrations. At the moment, the following connections work with FA Platform:

title: Use bank or custody connection
body: Bloomberg AIM. To receive files from Bloomberg AIM, set up the connection in FA Back (see Setting up Bloomberg AIM integration).

title: Use bank or custody connection
body: DNB Bank and custody connection. To receive files from DNB, set up the connection in FA Back (see Set up DNB bank and custody connection).

title: Use bank or custody connection
body: M2 Wealth. To receive files from M2 Wealth, set up the connection in FA Back (see Set up M2 Wealth).

title: Upload MT535 files in FA Back
body: If your reconciliation data is in MT535 format, follow the steps:

title: Upload MT535 files in FA Back
body: Open Tools → Import file → Reconciliation material in FA Back and select the file from your computer.

title: Upload MT535 files in FA Back
body: In the Destination for uploaded files, choose the format and if you want to perform the reconciliation based on the transaction date or settlement date of transactions.

title: Use FA reconciliation format
body: If your custodian provides the reconciliation data in a format that is not supported by FA Platform, you need to transform the data into the standard FA format first.

title: Create a reconciliation file
body: If your custodian provides the reconciliation data in any other format than MT535, you need to transform the data into the standard FA format first.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The reconciliation file in FA format is a CSV file with the following characteristics:

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The default field separator is a semicolon. You can configure FA to accept files with a different separator. The separator must be only one character.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The record separator must be \r\n (CRLF).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: Numbers must use "." (point) as a decimal separator and no thousands separator.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: If the file contains non-standard characters, the encoding must be ISO-8859-1.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: File name can be any.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The FA reconciliation needs to contain the following fields (use the field names as headers on the first row):

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: portfolio: Portfolio ID (as seen in the Portfolio window in FA Back).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: date: Date in the yyyy-MM-dd format (having two or more different dates in the file results in an error task and the file isn't processed).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: amount: Position amount or account balance.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: security: Any of securityCode / isin / tradeCode / updateCode1 / updateCode2 / updateCode3 is supported (either this or account is mandatory).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: account: Account number.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: currency: Optional. It’s recommended to include currency in the reconciliation file - the system uses this information to match positions and cash accounts in different currencies, in case they have the same ID or account number.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: tradeAmountPf: Optional. Position purchase value in portfolio currency.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: tradeAmount: Optional. Position purchase value in security currency.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: marketTradeAmountPf: Optional. Position market value in portfolio currency.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: marketTradeAmount: Optional. Position market value in security currency.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: Download the CSV file example:

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: fa_example_reconciliation_file.csv

title: Related links
body: Configure field separator for reconciliation files

title: Upload files in FA reconciliation format in FA Back
body: To upload a file in the FA reconciliation format in FA Back:

title: Upload files in FA reconciliation format in FA Back
body: Open Tools → Import file → Reconciliation material in FA Back and select the file from your computer.

title: Upload files in FA reconciliation format in FA Back
body: In the Destination for uploaded files, choose the format and if you want to perform the reconciliation based on the transaction date or settlement date of transactions.

title: Handle positions missing in the data source
body: You can define how reconciliation handles positions that are present in FA Platform but missing in the custodian data. By default, position reconciliation shows a mismatch if it finds extra positions that are present in FA Platform but missing in your custodian's reconciliation file. You can change this behavior by excluding a portfolio or a security from reconciliation.

title: Handle positions missing in the data source
body: Ignore all extra positions in the specified portfolio – for example, if the portfolio contains positions from multiple custodians, and the reconciliation is done custodian-by-custodian. To set up this option, open the Portfolio window, Basic info tab in FA Back and enable "Reconciliation: Ignore extra positions in FA".

title: Handle positions missing in the data source
body: Ignore extra positions in a certain security in all portfolios – for example, if the reconciled portfolios include unlisted assets that are missing from the reconciliation file provided by your custodian. To set up this option, open the Security window, Basic info tab in FA Back and enable "Reconciliation: Ignore extra positions in FA".

title: View positions and correct mismatches
body: This page describes how to reconcile data in FA Back. We recommend using FA Operations application for reconciliation. For instructions, see FA Operations.

title: View positions
body: View positions

title: View positions
body: You can view the reconciliation results in the Tasks view, Reconciliation dashboard. If there are any mismatches, open the task to see the details.

title: View positions
body: You can also view the portfolios with position reconciliation mismatches in the "Position reconciliation errors" dynamic portfolio group. You can find this group, for example, in the Overview.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: You can fix the reconciliation errors while having the window with reconciliation results open at the same time:

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Open the Reconciliation - Errors in the Portfolios view. Portfolios with errors have the "Reconciliation-Errors" tag and are listed in the view.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Choose the portfolio and click Reconcile → Positions at the bottom. The Reconcile portfolio window opens.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Choose the reconciliation date and click Reconcile. You will see the list of mismatching portfolio positions.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: While having the window open, correct portfolio positions in FA Back views if needed or use the Ignore to ignore an item.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Click Reconcile to re-run the reconciliation against updated content (and save ignored items), and show the new result.

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: I have my cash balance in the correct format, but the system says that the file amount is 0. How can I fix this?

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: Check out the decimal separator - it needs to be a dot (“.”).

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: My reconciliation gives POS_NFOUND errors, even if the portfolio has these positions. How can I fix this?

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: Check out the portfolio code: it can't have a comma inside the code.

title: Export FA data for reconciliation
body: You can export positions from FA to reconcile or update data in another FA instance, or in a third-party system that supports any of the provided file formats.

title: Export FA data for reconciliation
body: FA can export positions in the following file formats:

title: Export FA data for reconciliation
body: FA format (.csv)

title: Export FA data for reconciliation
body: SWIFT MT535 (.txt)

title: Export FA data for reconciliation
body: SQL query result (.xlsx)

title: Export FA data for reconciliation
body: FA can reconcile and update positions from FA format (.csv), and reconcile positions from SWIFT MT535 format (.txt) (see View positions and correct mismatches).

title: Generate FA format (CSV)
body: To generate a CSV file with positions:

title: Generate FA format (CSV)
body: Make sure the positions export and the Date offset are set up. For instructions, see Set up positions export in FA Admin guide.

title: Generate FA format (CSV)
body: Go to the Portfolios view and search for portfolios to export positions for.

title: Generate FA format (CSV)
body: Click Create report → Positions export at the bottom of the view.

title: Generate FA format (CSV)
body: As a result, positions are saved in the CSV format on disk, in /back-writable/integrations/positions. In addition, depending on configurations, they can be saved in the Tasks view or emailed to the addresses defined.

title: Generate FA format (CSV)
body: The task can be found with the "Query Positions export results" title.

title: Generate FA format (CSV)
body: Position export in CSV file can be scheduled if needed (see Scheduling processes in FA Admin guide).

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: The SWIFT MT535 file format is used to report, at a specified moment in time, the quantity and identification of financial instruments that the account servicer maintains for the account owner (for more information, see the MT535 specification). FA can export this file with position balances per transaction date or per settlement date. If generated for multiple portfolios, the output MT535 file contains one message per portfolio. Each message gets a unique header and reference.

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: To generate the SWIFT MT535 file:

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: Install one or both (depending on your need) optional packages below. For instructions, see Optional packages in FA Admin guide.

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: SWIFT MT535 (settlement date-based)

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: SWIFT MT535 (transaction date-based)

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: Add two ID entries to each of the portfolios you generate MT535 for. For instructions, see Portfolio window

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: External name: SenderBIC, External ID: The 8-character BIC of the sender of the MT535.

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: External name: ReceiverBIC, External ID: The 8-character BIC of the receiver of the MT535.

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: Add a Book entry to each of the target portfolios you generate the MT535 for. For instructions, see Basic info. The portfolio's Book entry corresponds to the ID of the Safekeeping Account at the receiver of the MT535.

title: Generate a SWIFT MT535 (TXT)
body: Open the Report window in FA Back and choose "SWIFT MT535 (settlement date-based)" or "SWIFT MT535 (transaction date-based) from the report list, a contact/portfolio/group of portfolios, a report date, and "TXT" as the file format. For more detailed instructions on how to generate reports, see Report window.

title: View positions with a pre-defined SQL query and export the results (XLSX)
body: You can view portfolio positions in FA Back:

title: View positions with a pre-defined SQL query and export the results (XLSX)
body: Open the Queries view (see Queries view) and choose the Positions export query tab.

title: View positions with a pre-defined SQL query and export the results (XLSX)
body: Select a portfolio from the drop-down and (optionally) define the End date to fetch the positions for (if you leave it empty, the current date is used).

title: View positions with a pre-defined SQL query and export the results (XLSX)
body: Export the results to your computer in XLSX format by clicking the icon at the top-right.

title: Tax reporting in Finland
body: Annual reporting for Finnish tax authorities package includes the following reports (for more information on report content, go to the Tax administration site):

title: Annual notification - Asset management fees (VSOMHOIE)
body: With this report, you can report fees from the management or custody of assets on a customer-by-customer basis in the format required by the Tax Administration.

title: Annual notification - Contact person (VSTVVYHT)
body: The report picks up the configured contact person information and arranges it according to the technical description.

title: Annual notification - Foreign dividends (VSULKOSE)
body: This annual notification report is for the Finnish tax authorities about foreign dividends.

title: Annual notification - Foreign dividends (VSULKOSE)
body: The report contains information on all the dividends from securities whose country code is not "FI".

title: Annual notification - Payments of interest, calling for withholding of tax at source (VSKTVYSL)
body: This report "Payments of interest, calling for withholding tax at source". Picking up these from the system is done by defining transaction types to look for, and then summed up of those transactions. Process will by default calculate the paid tax from transaction's tax fields including all tax types, but with configuration this can be narrowed to only selected tax types.

title: Annual notification - Payments of interest, calling for withholding of tax at source (VSKTVYSL)
body: The process currently supports only reporting of interest type 8B = Interest on bonds and debentures.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: This process creates an annual report of shares in funds and payments of interest.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: FA supports these types:

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 2B and 2G. With these types, the fund management company can report units and income units from its own funds.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 2D - Other interest or capital gains.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 2E - Secondary market credit paid by the issuer of the annual return to the taxable person (taxable capital gains).

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 2F - Post-market credit collected (received) by the issuer of the annual return from the taxable person (deduction in the taxable person's taxation).

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 3J - Return paid on a unit of a foreign UCITS.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 3K - Interest paid / transmitted outside the EU.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: This report is for reporting purchases, sales, capital gains and losses for securities and derivatives. Role 1 reporting is transaction-based, while roles 2-4 are reported per owned securities.

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: The FA supports the reporting of securities trading data with roles 1, 2, 3 and 4.

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: Reporting role 1 (reporting obligation of the securities intermediary) - the role reports all purchases and sales (excluding bonds, security type codes 07 and 57). The reporting obligation applies to both general and limited taxpayers in Finland.

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: Notifier role 2 (management company disclosure obligation) - the role is used to report redemptions under security type code 05.

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: Reporting role 3 (data for calculating gains and losses on disposals of securities) - the role is used to report sales (excluding bonds, security type codes 07, 45, 46 and 57). The obligation to notify applies to the sale of securities of natural persons and estates of taxable persons both in Finland in general and to a limited extent.

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: Notifier role 4 (instead of notifier role 3, obligation to declare bonds) - the role is used to report sales (including bonds, security type codes 07, 45, 46 and 57).

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: If both notifier roles 3 and 4 are selected, notifier roles 3 report non-bond sales and notifier roles 4 report only bond sales.

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: If both notifier roles 1 and 4 are selected, no annual notification with notifier role 1 will be issued for sales reported with notifier role 4.

title: Annual notification - Purchases and sales (VSAPUUSE)
body: If both Advertiser Roles 1 and 3 are selected, then the same sales will be referenced

title: Tax reporting in Finland
body: Annual reporting for Finnish tax authorities package includes the following reports (for more information on report content, go to the Tax administration site):

title: Annual notification - Asset management fees (VSOMHOIE)
body: With this report, you can report fees from the management or custody of assets on a customer-by-customer basis in the format required by the Tax Administration.

title: Annual notification - Contact person (VSTVVYHT)
body: The report picks up the configured contact person information and arranges it according to the technical description.

title: Annual notification - Foreign dividends (VSULKOSE)
body: This annual notification report is for the Finnish tax authorities about foreign dividends.

title: Annual notification - Foreign dividends (VSULKOSE)
body: The report contains information on all the dividends from securities whose country code is not "FI".

title: Annual notification - Payments of interest, calling for withholding of tax at source (VSKTVYSL)
body: This report "Payments of interest, calling for withholding tax at source". Picking up these from the system is done by defining transaction types to look for, and then summed up of those transactions. Process will by default calculate the paid tax from transaction's tax fields including all tax types, but with configuration this can be narrowed to only selected tax types.

title: Annual notification - Payments of interest, calling for withholding of tax at source (VSKTVYSL)
body: The process currently supports only reporting of interest type 8B = Interest on bonds and debentures.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: This process creates an annual report of shares in funds and payments of interest.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: FA supports these types:

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 2B and 2G. With these types, the fund management company can report units and income units from its own funds.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 2D - Other interest or capital gains.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 2E - Secondary market credit paid by the issuer of the annual return to the taxable person (taxable capital gains).

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 2F - Post-market credit collected (received) by the issuer of the annual return from the taxable person (deduction in the taxable person's taxation).

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 3J - Return paid on a unit of a foreign UCITS.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 3K - Interest paid / transmitted outside the EU.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 3L - Foreign UCITS share.

title: Annual notification - Profits and shares (VSTVERIE)
body: 3M - Interest paid / transferred from another EU Member State.

title: Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities
body: Configurable key figures allow you to define what key figure values you want to store on your contacts, portfolios and securities. Key figures allow you to store a time series of values of your choice. For example, you can store fee percentages that change over time to your portfolios, or your key figure on your instruments, extending the possibilities of storing data into FA.

title: Rebalance window
body: You can create model portfolios, strategies or investment plans and use them to keep your investment portfolios in balance. Rebalancing creates trade orders to buy and sell securities according to the model. For general information about rebalancing approaches and for instructions, see Rebalance in FA User guide.

title: Rebalance window
body: The Rebalance window allows you to define the rebalance parameters and the securities to rebalance. The window lists securities in the portfolio or in the model linked to the rebalanced portfolio and indicates the shares of these securities in the investment portfolio and model. The portfolio account is also included in rebalancing.

title: Rebalance window
body: At the top of the Rebalance window, you can define the rebalancing parameters.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Affected portfolios

title: Affected portfolios
body: The Affected portfolios section defines which portfolios are rebalanced.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Rebalance against

title: Affected portfolios
body: Target for rebalancing, in order of descending priority. The system uses the first target in the list if defined. Otherwise, the system the target with the next highest priority. The targets can be:

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Model portfolio", "Investment plan", "Strategy" – Model portfolio, investment plan or strategy linked to the portfolio.

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Portfolio itself" – Target shares you specify in the Rebalance window.

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Empty portfolio" – An option to empty the portfolio – this will set all the new shares as 0% and sell everything, regardless of the linked model or plan.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Include sub-portfolios

title: Affected portfolios
body: Aggregates positions and investment plan/ model portfolio contents also from the rebalanced portfolio's subportfolios. This allows you to divide holdings into subportfolios and rebalance everything at once through the main portfolio. Trade orders are created either to the main portfolio or the sub-portfolios based on which portfolio or portfolio's investment plan / model portfolio the trade order's security can be found in: for sells of existing positions, trade orders are created in the same portfolio where the position currently is, and for buys, trade orders are created in the same portfolio which has the position in the investment plan / model portfolio.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Asset group

title: Affected portfolios
body: The asset group the strategy is based on (for example, geographical, industry, or asset class).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Date

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The rebalancing date. This date affects:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The market prices, rebalanced portfolio shares, trade order amounts. The percentage shares of securities in the portfolio are determined based on the market prices on the rebalancing date. The market prices on this date are used to calculate the amount in the suggested trade orders.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The content of the model portfolio/ investment plan. The target shares are fetched based on the selected rebalancing date

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Restrict rebalancing to accounts

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Restrict rebalancing to only reach the target level for portfolio accounts, without any other buys or sells. This feature has different effects depending on the rebalance method (buying with extra cash or using cash from sells) – see Choose rebalance method.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With the conservative rebalancing method, securities are bought and sold only to achieve the target level of the account. If the account has excess cash, the selected securities (largest first) are bought as long as there is available cash but nothing is sold. If the account has a lack of cash, the selected securities (largest first) are sold until the account reaches the target level - nothing is bought and securities are sold only to rebalance the account to the defined level.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With the exchange method, if the account balance is below the target, it is first rebalanced with sells. After this, the excess cash from sells is used to buy the securities to be rebalanced, but securities are sold only to cover all the necessary buys. If there are Executable sell trade orders, the cash coming in from these is taken into account when selling the securities.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With full rebalance, if the account balance is below the target, it is first rebalanced with sells. After this, the excess cash from sells is used to buy the securities to be rebalanced, but securities are sold only to cover all the necessary buys.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: You can also define the rebalance settings in Preference ("Define target range for portfolio's cash balance", "Define how much negative cash balance is increased by to cover all negative cash" and "Define how much positive cash balance is decreased by to ensure positive cash balance"). These preferences determine how rebalancing tries to achieve the target level for accounts. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalance method

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalancing approach: conservative rebalance, full rebalance, full rebalance including outstanding orders, exchange, invest cash, cover for cash, and model change (see Choose rebalance method).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Buy with

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Cash to use for buys:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Current cash only. With this option, you can align the portfolio with the model in two rounds. First, the system sells the excess positions and buys with the current cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys more positions with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Buy trade orders reduce the current cash.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Cash from sells only. With this option, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. You can also rebalance one position and swap it for another without rebalancing your entire portfolio. Cash from suggested sells is estimated based on the latest market prices.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you have enough cash to complete the buys.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Current cash and cash from sells. With this option, you can align the portfolio with the model in one go. Cash from suggested sells is estimated based on the latest prices.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Buy trade orders reduce the current cash.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Current cash, cash from sells and from orders. With this option, you can align the portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders. Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected to be available after executing these orders.Cash from suggested sells and outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") is estimated based on the latest prices.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you have enough cash to complete the buys.

title: Rebalance parameters
