title: Run simulations
body: In the simulation mode, you can try out what-if scenarios and see how portfolios will be affected if positions are changed. Once you are satisfied with your analysis, you can produce trade orders based on the simulations.

title: Run simulations
body: To define what-if scenarios and produce simulations based on them:

title: Run simulations
body: Open the PnL view. Set the table columns and grouping.

title: Run simulations
body: Switch to the simulation mode at the top-right. You can see the Simulated values section in the table.

title: Run simulations
body: If needed, lock the positions or groups you want to keep unchanged (deselect them on the left).

title: Run simulations
body: Make changes in the Simulated values section. You can edit position or group rows:

title: Run simulations
body: Adjust position or group values, such as Units, Market value or Share of pf %. When you change the group-level figures, the child positions are updated proportionally to their shares in the group.

title: Run simulations
body: Edit the diff values, such as Diff. units, Diff. market value or Diff. share %.

title: Run simulations
body: Enter the scaling % of the position. For example, -5 will decrease the position or group market value by 5%.

title: Run simulations
body: Every time you edit a value, other values in the table are adjusted accordingly. The changes also affect cash accounts. If you reduce the positions' market value, the cash balance increases. Conversely, increasing the positions' market value decreases the cash balance.

title: Run simulations
body: Click <arrow> at the bottom of the page to view buy and sell simulations that the system creates based on your scenario. If needed, you can undo the changes you modeled by deleting a simulation.

title: Rebalance
body: Rebalancing helps you align your portfolio positions with your model – a model portfolio, investment plan, strategy or the shares you specify. The system compares portfolios with the target model and generates trade orders for positions that deviated outside the minimum and maximum thresholds specified in the model.

title: Rebalance logic
body: When a portfolio is rebalanced, the system creates the trade orders based on the following logic.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Estimates the excess cash by checking if the portfolio's account balance is above the share of cash in the model. The estimation includes the accounts you chose and the cash from sells, if chosen.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Compares portfolio positions to the model:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Calculates the difference for each position in portfolio currency.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Calculates the number of units you would need based on the difference in portfolio currency and the market price on the selected date. Number of shares is calculated with as many decimals as defined in security type preferences, or overridden with the security block size.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Creates trade orders:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Buy trade orders are created first. Then the system creates sell trade orders. Buy trade orders are created, from largest to smallest, as long as there is excess cash in the portfolio. The last trade order might be only partially fulfilled. Sell trade orders are created with the same logic: from largest to smallest, until the target cash balance is reached.

title: Rebalance logic
body: If the difference per position measured in portfolio currency doesn't match a whole number of units (see the previous step), the system adjusts the trade orders following the logic defined in the rebalancing settings in FA Back preferences. Trade orders are recalculated based on:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Amount (using the calculated number of units and difference, and recalculating the unit price)

title: Rebalance logic
body: Trade amount (using the calculated number of units and unit price, and recalculating the trade amount)

title: Rebalance logic
body: For details, see "Create trade orders based on trade amount" and "Create trade orders based on trade amount" in Preference - Portfolios preferences in FA Back)

title: Rebalancing against strategy
body: Strategy rebalancing makes sure your portfolio follows allocation shares defined in the strategy. If an asset type is below or above the target, the system suggests buys or sells for the securities in the asset type. If an asset type is missing from the portfolio (for example, the strategy requires 10% Finnish stocks but the portfolio doesn't have any), the system suggests equally-sized trade orders for each security in the missing asset type from your buy list.

title: Rebalancing against strategy
body: Strategy rebalancing doesn't adjust holdings within the asset type. For example, if Finnish holdings in the portfolio are represented by one security, rebalancing considers this sufficient. It doesn't suggest sells to buy other Finnish stocks from the buy list.

title: Rebalancing against strategy
body: Strategy rebalancing works only for equity portfolios. It should not be used with funds and ETFs that are allocated to several asset types (for example, a fund security can be allocated as 70% US and 30% Canada).

title: Rebalancing portfolio cash
body: To keep portfolio's cash on a certain level, include the currency security as a position in the target. For example, if you have EUR accounts in your portfolio and want to have 1% cash in euros, add the currency security EUR with a target share of 1%.

title: Rebalancing portfolio cash
body: For the system-wide settings related to accounts and cash buffers in rebalancing, see Preference - Portfolios preferences in FA Back.

title: Market prices
body: Rebalancing uses market prices and FX rates available in FA platform, picking up the latest values in relation to the selected rebalancing date. You can choose to use the 15-minute delayed market prices from your market data provider. To do this, edit preferences in FA Back: see Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Trade orders: based on amount or number of units
body: The system adjusts the trade amount or the number of units in the trade order if they don't match (for example, you need to buy for 300€, the unit price is 80€, and the security is traded in whole units). You can choose to create trade orders based on trade amount or number of units in the settings (see Preference - Portfolios preferencesin FA Back).

title: Trade orders: based on amount or number of units
body: The number of units in the trade order is calculated with the number of decimals defined in security type preferences in FA Back, or taken from the security's block size (if it is specified).

title: Trade orders: based on amount or number of units
body: To prevent the creation of small trade orders when the investment portfolio only slightly deviates from the target, you can set the minimum trade order amount when you rebalance.

title: Selling an entire position
body: Rebalancing recognizes when you sell out the entire position by removing it from the target. In this case:

title: Selling an entire position
body: The minimum trade amount of the orders has no effect - the sell orders are generated without size restrictions.

title: Selling an entire position
body: The amount of the order isn't adjusted, but corresponds with the current position amount in the portfolio.

title: Selling an entire position
body: If rebalancing is restricted to accounts, entire positions are not sold unless there is "room to sell" based on the target cash balance.

title: Selling an entire position
body: Rebalancing marks such trade orders by creating them with a separate transaction type, as configured in "Select the transaction type used for trade orders when selling an entire position" in Rebalancing preferences (see Preference - Portfolios). Rebalancing creates these trade orders as unit-based.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: You can include future contracts in the target. Rebalancing of future contracts depends on the security type settings defined in FA Back (Preference - Securities - Security types).

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: If the Future contract setting is set to "Yes - charge cost later": Buying a future based on the rebalance target share doesn't deduct the available cash.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: If the Future contract setting is set to "Yes - charge cost immediately": Buying a future based on the rebalance target share deducts costs from the available cash, if you choose to apply fees to trade orders when you rebalance.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: For both options, selling a future doesn't add to the available cash if one of the options for using cash from sells is used.

title: Collateral in rebalancing
body: To manage collateral in rebalancing, transfer collateral positions from the main portfolio into a locked sub-portfolio. When rebalancing the main portfolio, the collateral positions from the sub-portfolio are taken into account when determining how much to buy or sell in total, but the collateralized positions in the locked sub-portfolio are not touched.

title: Related links
body: Model portfolio management in FA Back reference

title: Related links
body: Model Portfolio Management and Rebalancing in FA Product description

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: To rebalance portfolios and positions, make sure you have:

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: Rebalance preferences defined in FA Back (see in Preference - Portfolios).

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: Rebalance model (model portfolio, investmetn plan or strategy) set up in FA Back (see Investment objectives). Rebalance model is not required – you can also define the target values ad hoc when you rebalance.

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: For strategy rebalancing, the buy list of securities linked to investment portfolios. Buy list is used to add more positions in the asset type. To learn more about creating a buy list in Fa Back, see Create a buy list for strategy rebalancing in FA User guide.

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: Rebalancing in FA Invest includes the following steps:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: To start the rebalancing, set up the table to view current positions and target values:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Open the portfolios in the PnL view. Click the Rebalance positions button next to the portfolio group, portfolio or position you want to rebalance.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Choose the model to use for rebalancing:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Base for rebalancing

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Base for the rebalance target:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Model portfolio, investment plan or strategy linked to the portfolio.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Current positions – current portfolio positions that you can adjust to create target shares.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Asset group

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: The asset group of the strategy that you want to use for rebalancing. This option is shown if you chose strategy as a base.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Include all positions from model

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Show the buy list positions with zero amounts that can be adjusted. This option is shown if you chose strategy as a base.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Once you chose the base for rebalancing, you can see the Position details and Model details sections showing the current and model shares.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Set up the table to group current and target values and show the relevant columns:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Group positions in the table: click Columns on the right and drag the grouping parameter (for example, security type or asset type) to the top of the table.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Choose the columns you want to view, for example, Share of pf. % in Position details and columns in the Model details section.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Now you can see the current positions and the model shares in the rebalance table. You can proceed to choosing rebalance method and defining other rebalance options.

title: Choose rebalance method
body: Decide which rebalance method you want to use. Rebalance method is the approach to rebalancing that defines how much the portfolio is adjusted to bring it in line with target. The rebalance method you choose affects the rebalance options defined in the next step.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: With conservative rebalance, you can buy only with the cash in the portfolio account. You can realign the portfolio with the model in two rounds. In the first round, the system sells the excess positions above the target and buys with the available cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys more with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect conservative rebalance in the following way:

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: Buy trade orders reduce the available cash for buys.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you need to buy something but you already have a buy trade order, or if you need to sell but already have a sell trade order, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: Example: You need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: To apply the conservative rebalance method, choose "Current cash only" option in the Buy with field when you rebalance.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: With full rebalance, you can buy securities with available cash and the cash expected from suggested sells. This method calculates buys based on the estimated cash you will have after executing suggested sales with the latest market prices. With full rebalance, you can realign portfolios against the target in one go.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect full rebalancing in the following way:

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: Buy trade orders reduce the available cash for buys.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you need to buy something but you already have a buy trade order, or if you need to sell but already have a sell trade order, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: Example: You need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: To apply the conservative rebalance method, choose "Current cash and cash from sells" option in the Buy with field when you rebalance.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: With full rebalance including outstanding orders, you can buy securities with available cash, expected cash from suggested sells, and cash from outstanding trade orders with a positive cash effect (all statuses except "Open"), such as deposits and sells. Full rebalance estimates available cash that will be received after executing all sells with the latest market prices.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected from executing these orders. With full rebalance including outstanding trade orders, you can realign your entire portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: To apply this method, choose "Current cash, cash from sells and from orders" option in the Buy with field when you rebalance.

title: Exchange
body: With exchange, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. The cash received from sells is estimated based on the latest market prices.

title: Exchange
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Exchange
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect exchange rebalancing in the following way:

title: Exchange
body: Buy trade orders reduce the available cash for buys.

title: Exchange
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you need to buy something but you already have a buy trade order, or if you need to sell but already have a sell trade order, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Exchange
body: Example: You need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Exchange
body: To apply this method, choose "Cash from sells only" option in the Buy with field when you rebalance. Select the positions you want to exchange.

title: Model change
body: With the model change, you can update your portfolio model by selling the securities from the old model and investing everything into the securities in the new model.

title: Model change
body: You have an option to execute a model change either as conservative rebalancing (buying with current cash) or full rebalancing (buying with current cash, cash from sells and, optionally, cash from orders), depending on whether you prefer to do it gradually or all at once. Regardless of the method chosen, rebalancing will sell off your old positions entirely and reinvest the proceeds into the new positions.

title: Define rebalance options
body: Rebalance options above the table let you control cash usage, as well as trade order size and fees.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Buy with

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Cash to use for buys:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Current cash only. With this option, you can align the portfolio with the model in two rounds. First, the system sells the excess positions and buys with the current cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys more positions with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Buy trade orders reduce the current cash.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Cash from sells only. With this option, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. You can also rebalance one position and swap it for another without rebalancing your entire portfolio. Cash from suggested sells is estimated based on the latest market prices.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you have enough cash to complete the buys.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Current cash and cash from sells. With this option, you can align the portfolio with the model in one go. Cash from suggested sells is estimated based on the latest prices.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Buy trade orders reduce the current cash.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Current cash, cash from sells and from orders. With this option, you can align the portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders. Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected to be available after executing these orders.Cash from suggested sells and outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") is estimated based on the latest prices.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you have enough cash to complete the buys.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use cash from accounts

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Accounts to use for buys if you select to buy with extra cash in the portfolio. This option allows you to keep your portfolio fully invested and exclude certain accounts (for example, accrued fee accounts) from rebalancing.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "All accounts" – Use cash on all accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Cash accounts" – Use cash on the accounts marked as "cash accounts" in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab in FA Back.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Cash and credit accounts" – Use cash on cash and credit accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Default account only" – Use cash on the portfolio's default account – the first account in the list in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab in FA Back. If this account is a credit account, you can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Filter out small trade orders based on

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The minimum size for the trade orders that rebalancing should create. The size restrictions don't apply if you sell an entire position away from the portfolio. Set the minimum difference between the portfolio position and the model as:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Diff %pt" – The difference in percentage points.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Diff %" – The relative difference in percentage.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Trade amount" – The minimum trade amount in portfolio currency. Alternatively, you can define a Minimum trade amount for each of your securities in FA Back (see Security window).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Model min/max share" – The difference defined with the minimum and maximum thresholds in the model. Trade orders are created only if the position deviates outside of the minimum and maximum thresholds. The minimum trade amount for each trade order is calculated as follows:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: For "buy": ( target share - min share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance parameters
body: For "sell": ( max share - target share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Positions that don't have the thresholds specified in the model are rebalanced without filtering when "Position is within min/max share" is selected.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Apply fees to trade orders

title: Rebalance parameters
body: An option to calculate fees, or to estimate the effect of an upcoming fee when generating buy and sell trade orders. If a fee is calculated, the effect of the fee is taken into account when determining how many units you can buy with you available cash and how much money you get from sells. This allows you to estimate the effects of upcoming transaction fees more accurately. Fees are also saved in the Fees field for each trade order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "No fees" – Don't include fees in trade orders.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Portfolio-specific fees" – Include a transaction fee defined for the portfolio in FA Back (Portfolio window, Fees tab).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Fixed fees" – Include a fee defined as a percentage in the field available next to the selection.

title: Adjust target values
body: If needed, you can adjust the target values further by adding positions or editing values:

title: Adjust target values
body: To add a position in the list, click Add position. Select the security and portfolio and click Add. Remember that yo can add all securities that are included in the strategy buy list by selecting Include all positions from model .

title: Adjust target values
body: To exclude some positions from rebalancing, select the rows and click Exclude positions.

title: Adjust target values
body: To adjust target values one by one, edit the Target values section of the table.

title: Adjust target values
body: To adjust several position values, select the asset type positions and click Edit positions. Fill in the fields:

title: Adjustment fields
body: Column

title: Adjustment fields
body: The value you want to adjust:

title: Adjustment fields
body: Share of pf. % – Enter target position share.

title: Adjustment fields
body: Units – Enter target number of units.

title: Adjustment fields
body: Market value – Enter target market value.

title: Adjustment fields
body: Diff. share – Increase or decrease the target positions share the specified percentage (for decreasing, use the minus sign).

title: Adjustment fields
body: Diff. units – Increase or decrease target positions units by the specified number (for decreasing, use the minus sign).

title: Adjustment fields
body: Diff. market value – Increase or decrease positions market value by the specified amount (for decreasing, use the minus sign).

title: Adjustment fields
body: Value

title: Adjustment fields
body: The adjustment value.

title: Adjustment fields
body: Method

title: Adjustment fields
body: The option to choose how the adjustment value is applied to the selected positions:

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Apply to all rows" – Apply the value to positions.

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Distribute the value evenly" – Divide the value equally among positions. For example, distribute €1,000 across 5 positions to add €200 to each.

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Distribute based on current position" – Distribute the value proportional to each position's current market value. Example: Distributing €100,000 ("Diff. market value") among positions with values of €50,000, €150,000, and €300,000 adds €10,000, €30,000, and €60,000, respectively.

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Distribute based on model position" – Distribute the value based on the model shares. Example: Distributing €100,000 ("Diff. market value") in a portfolio of €1,000,000 to positions with model shares of 10%, 20%, and 20% adds €20,000, €40,000, and €40,000.

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Distribute based on portfolio market value" – Distribute the value proportional to the portfolio’s total market value. Example: Adding 100 units ("Diff. units") of stock to portfolios with values of €1,000,000, €1,500,000, and €2,500,000 increases units by 20, 30, and 50, respectively.

title: Check and create suggested trade orders
body: Once you are satisfied with the target values you see, you can proceed to trade order preview.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: # Code Required Name Description

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 1 tr.parentPortfolio Yes Portfolio ID String (unique ID of the transaction's portfolio)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 2 tr.extId No Transaction External ID External ID / number of you transaction. If left empty, an external ID is generated for the transaction by the system. In addition, system defines an internal ID as well. External ID is used in combination with #1 Portfolio ID to update existing transactions - if your external ID already exists, the existing transaction is updated.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 3 tr.type Yes Type Type code (configured in the system). E.g. buy, sell etc.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 4 tr.status No Status Define as a code: OK = Accepted DEL = Deleted NF = Not finished

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 5 tr.transactionDate Yes Transaction date yyyy-MM-dd

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 6 tr.settlementDate No Settlement date yyyy-MM-dd In addition, you can use numbers between 1 and 99 to set the settlement date (the settlement date is set the inserted number of business days after the transaction date). The transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 7 tr.maturityDate No Maturity date Not used. Only available for transactions on securities with base type DEPOSIT (not regular deposit transactions). Use format yyyy-MM-dd.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 8 tr.security No Security Security code of the transaction's security. Leave empty, if a cash transaction. In addition to security code, importing transactions is supported with ISIN code, trade code or update codes 1 through 3. When importing transactions by using ISIN code to identify the security, the system checks that the transaction’s currency (column #11 Currency) matches the found security’s currency, if there are multiple securities with the same ISIN code in the system.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 9 tr.securityType No Security type Security type code of the transaction's security's type (as configured in the system). Used to determine features of a transaction.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 10 tr.account No Account Account number, if transaction is directed to an account. You can use the an account linked to the portfolio or shared to the portfolio. Define AUTO to record the transactions to the account with the same currency as the transaction, if such an account is found, or to the default account of the portfolio, if suitable currency account is not found. Define DEFAULT to always direct the transaction to the portfolio's default account. The system ignores white spaces in account numbers, and is thus able to recognize account numbers (such as IBAN numbers) defined with or without white spaces.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 11 tr.currency No Currency Transaction's currency (define with the currency code). If you don't define a currency for your transaction, the system will automatically determine it based on your transaction's data (available from FA 3.9 onward). Transaction's currency is either 1) Transaction's security's currency (if transaction is linked to a security) 2) Transaction's account's currency (for transactions not linked to a security but linked to account, i.e. CASH transactions) 3) Transaction's portfolio's currency (for transactions not linked to a security nor account, i.e. CASH transactions with "No account") After 3.9, best practice is to leave the currency empty, and the system will determine it for you. Before FA 3.9, transaction's currency was a mandatory field: define the currency with the currency security's code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 12 tr.amount Yes Amount Number of units/denomination of the transaction. The tr.amount field accepts the amount of decimals allowed for the transaction. If your file has more decimals in the amount, the amount is rounded to contain only accepted amount of decimals. For cash transactions, the number of decimals is defined per account (see Portfolio window), per currency security in the Block size field (see Security window) or per security type in Preferences (see Preferences - Securities). For the other transactions, the number of decimals is can be defined per account (see Portfolio window) or taken from the decimal format Preferences. When importing new transactions, if number of units is not available, you can leave it empty so the system calculates the amount with "unitPrice" (#13) and "tradeAmount" (#14). When updating existing transactions, make sure the field has the correct value, or let the FA system calculate the value by including the empty field in the import file (or API call). For transactions with amortized bonds, define "AUTO" to fetch the outstanding principal amount. Make sure you also import the original principal amount in tr.principalAmount – it is used by the system to calculate the outstanding principal.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 13 tr.unitPrice Yes Unit price Unit price is security currency (trade currency). Define AUTO to automatically use the transaction day's market data entry. For bonds, unit price can be set with % (e.g. 3.45%), when the system calculates the price according to YTM automatically. When importing new transactions, if unit price is not available or is inaccurate, you can leave it empty, so the system calculates the unit price with "amount" (#12) and "tradeAmount" (#14). When updating existing transactions, make sure the field has the correct value, or let the FA system calculate the value by including the empty field in the import file (or API call).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 14 tr.tradeAmount Yes Trade amount Value of the transaction in security currency (trade currency), i.e. money value of the transaction including costs, taxes, accrued interest etc. When importing new transactions, if trade amount is not available, you can leave it empty, so the system calculates the trade amount with "amount" (#12) and "unitPrice" (#13). When updating existing transactions, make sure the field has the correct value, or let the FA system calculate the value by including the empty field in the import file (or API call).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 15 tr.fxRate No FX rate Exchange rate for the transaction. Define the exchange rate in the direction of the matching currency cross which has been defined in the FA system. When importing an FX rate, the system automatically determines whether the exchange rate is account exchange rate (column #41) and/or report exchange rate (column #42), and fills them in appropriately. Define AUTO to automatically use the transaction day's market data entry.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 16 tr.tax No Tax Tax in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 17 tr.cost No Cost Fee in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 18 tr.cost2 No Cost 2 Credit fee in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 19 tr.origTransactionDate No Booked transaction date yyyy-MM-dd

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 20 tr.origUnitPrice No Booked unit price Booked unit price in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 21 tr.origTradeAmount No Booked trade amount Booked trade amount. Define AUTO to automatically calculate the booked trade amount by multiplying the amount with transaction day's market data entry.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 22 tr.origFxRate No Booked FX rate Booked exchange rate between trade currency and portfolio's report currency. Define the exchange rate in the direction of the matching currency cross which has been defined in the FA system. Define AUTO to automatically use the original transaction day's market data entry.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 23 tr.accruedInterest No Accrued interest Accrued interest in trade currency. For bonds, the accrued interest can be set with "?", when the system calculates the accrued interest automatically. Define AUTO to automatically calculate the accrued interest.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 24 tr.reference No Reference Reference of the transaction, usually transaction's reference number. Reference is used in combination with #1 Portfolio ID to update existing transactions if you haven't defined #2 External ID in your import file - if your reference can be found from an existing transaction, the existing transaction is updated.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 25 tr.counter No Counter Counter (use contact ID)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 26 tr.counterPortfolio No Counter portfolio Counter portfolio (use portfolio code)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: (27) (Ext info) Not used. Use tr.description in column #31 instead.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 28 tr.intInfo No Internal info Internal transaction description

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 29 tr.basis No Basis Not used.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 30 tr.priority No Priority Intraday priority of a transaction. -1,1,2,3... The transaction with the lowest priority has the highest number defined in the priority field (0 is lower than 1 and -1 is lower than 0). The default priority is 0.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 31 tr.description No Description Description/comment on the transaction

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 32 tr.security2 No Security 2 Security code of the removed security (e.g. in the exchange, the one that is replaced)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 33 tr.ratio No Ratio Define the ratio with syntax x:x (e.g. 1:2 or 2:3.25). Ratio is used for example for splits and exchanges. For splits, define the ratio between the number of securities before and after the split (with ratio 1:2, one security before the split would become two securities after the split). For exchanges, define the ratio as how many new securities are received with one removed security (with ratio 1:2, one removed security would become two new securities after the exchange).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 34 tr.taxType No Tax type Tax type of the transaction defined with the tax type code

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 35 tr.marketPlace No Market place Use the exchange code / market place code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 36 tr.tradeTime No Trade time hh:mm:ss You can also define the trade time with time zone information with the syntax of hh:mm:ssContinent/City (e.g. 11:12:13Europe/Helsinki, use valid java time zones) - when the transaction is imported, the trade time is converted into the server's time zone.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 37 tr.tax2 No Tax 2 Tax in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 38 tr.taxType2 No Tax 2 type Tax type of the transaction defined with the tax type code

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 39 tr.tags No Tags The "Tags" field is a comma-separated list of tags that you can use to categorize your transactions.To add a tag: Standalone tags can be added by simply typing the tag name. For example, if you want to add a Fund tag and an Urgent tag, you can add them like this: "Fund,Urgent".Single-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>-<tag name>. For example, if you want to add a tag for an office location in Helsinki, you can add it like this: "office-Helsinki". If a transaction already has a tag with the same group name, the new tag will replace the old one.Multi-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>, etc. For example, if you want to add tags to your Campaign group, you can add them like this: "Campaign:EarlyBird,Campaign:Friends". If a transaction already has tags with the same group name, the new tags will be added to the existing ones. To remove a tag, use the syntax "---" followed by the tag name or tag group name. For example: To remove a standalone tag for "Fund", you can use "---Fund".To remove a single-select group tag for "office-Helsinki", you can use "---office-Helsinki".To remove multi-select group tags for "Campaign:EarlyBird" and "Campaign:Friends", you can use "---Campaign:EarlyBird,---Campaign:Friends". For details, see Removing transaction and trade order values with three minuses (---).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 40 tr.settlementPlace No Settlement place Use the settlement code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 41 tr.accountFxRate No Account FX rate Exchange rate between trade currency and portfolio's account currency. Define the exchange rate in the direction of the matching currency cross which has been defined in the FA system. Define AUTO to automatically use the transaction day's market data entry. If you are not sure whether you need the account or report FX rate, use FX rate (column #15) instead, which automatically determines which one to use.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 42 tr.reportFxRate No Report FX rate Exchange rate between trade currency and portfolio's report currency. Define the exchange rate in the direction of the matching currency cross which has been defined in the FA system. Define AUTO to automatically use the transaction day's market data entry. If you are not sure whether you need the account or report FX rate, use FX rate (column #15) instead, which automatically determines which one to use.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 43 tr.coefficient No Coefficient Coefficient calculated from the linked security's price and index base value. Affects trade amount same as unit price. Define AUTO to automatically calculate coefficient on the transaction date from the linked security and index base value.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 44 tr.compCost1 No Break-down of cost 1 Define the break-down of costs as a list of transaction cost data with the syntax <type>=<value>. Types are from defined transaction cost type. E.g. BROK=15,ADV=22. If you also defined a Cost (column #17), your Break-down of cost 1 has to sum up to the total cost you defined! If you leave Cost empty, the system calculates it automatically as the sum of your break-down of costs.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 45 tr.compCost2 No Break-down of cost 2 Define the break-down of costs as a list of transaction cost data with the syntax <type>=<value>. Types are from defined transaction cost type. E.g. BROK=15,ADV=22. If you also defined a Cost 2 (column #18), your Break-down of cost 2 has to sum up to the total cost you defined! If you leave Cost empty, the system calculates it automatically as the sum of your break-down of costs.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 46 tr.costType1 No Transaction cost type 1 Type of selected transaction cost type. Value is from defined transaction cost type's type code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 47 tr.costType2 No Transaction cost type 2 Type of selected transaction cost type. Value is from defined transaction cost type's type code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 48 tr.hidden No Hidden Whether the transaction should be marked as hidden. Define as a number: 1 = Hidden 0 = Not hidden (default)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 49 tr.paymentDate No Payment date yyyy-MM-dd

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 50 tr.accrual No Accrual Transaction's accrual, or the the paid/received accrued income which is recorded as part of the price (unit price x amount). Accrual has no effect of the trade amount

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 51 tr.receiveDate No Receive date yyyy-MM-dd

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 52 tr.receiveTime No Receive time hh:mm:ss You can also define the receive time with time zone information with the syntax of hh:mm:ssContinent/City (e.g. 11:12:13Europe/Helsinki, use valid java time zones) - when the trade order is imported, the time is converted into the server's time zone.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 53 tr.accrual2 No Removed accrual Removed accrual from security A when making an Exchange for security B.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 54 tr.overrideFifoTransactionExtId No Override FIFO (ext ID) List the external transaction IDs that represent purchase lots, separated by commas without spaces. Example: 5,12,8.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 55 tr.principalAmount No Principal Original principal amount of the bond.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: # Code Required Name Description

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 1 p.shortName Yes Portfolio ID Text or number uniquely identifying a portfolio. When creating a new portfolio, define AUTO to automatically use the next available number as the portfolio ID, if the "Generate a running number for portfolio ID automatically" is enabled in Portfolios Preferences.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 2 p.name Yes Name Portfolio name

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 3 p.creationDate No Creation date yyyy-MM-dd. Date when the portfolio was created.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 4 p.extId No External ID External contract ID such as book-entry account number

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 5 p.status Yes Status Use the code of the status: A = Active P = Passive C = Closed

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 6 p.type Yes Type Type code (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 7 Match type Not used.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 8 p.currency Yes Reporting currency Reporting currency code.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 10 p.info1 No Info 1 Open text field

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 11 p.info2 No Info 2 Open text field

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 12 p.info3 No Info 3 Open text field

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 13 p.notes No Notes Text, notes or memo on the portfolio.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 14 p.valuationMethod No Valuation method Use the code of the valuation methods: FIFO (default)FIFOP = FIFO (combined)AVER = Average priceAVER2 = Average price with adjustmentsAVER3 = Average price with separate items.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 15 p.language Yes Language Language code (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 16 p.primaryContact No Primary contact Primary contact (contact ID). To import representative tag values, add them after ###: Add standalone tags as <representative's contact ID>###<tag name 1>#<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Standalone1#Standalone2Add single-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name 1>#<group name>-<tag name 2>. For example: 258258###Permission-View#Relationship type-AdvisorAdd multi-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>#<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission for trade orders:Make#Permission for trade orders:ModifyTo import multiple types of tags simultaneously, separate the tags with #. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Employee:Finance#Employee:Accounting#Relationship type-Advisor#Standalone1#Standalone2

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 17 p.contact No Other contacts Portfolio's other contacts. Contact IDs as a comma-separated list. To import representative tag values, add them after ###: Add standalone tags as <representative's contact ID>###<tag name 1>#<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Standalone1#Standalone2Add single-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name 1>#<group name>-<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Relationship type-AdvisorAdd multi-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>#<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission for trade orders:Make#Permission for trade orders:ModifyTo import multiple types of tags simultaneously, separate the tags with #. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Employee:Finance#Employee:Accounting#Relationship type-Advisor#Standalone1#Standalone2

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 18 Default account Not used.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 19 p.accounts No Accounts  A colon-separated (:) list of the portfolio accounts. To add accounts to a portfolio, use the following syntax: <Account no.>,<Currency with currency code>,<Name>,<Visibility as 0=not visible 1=visible>,<Shared as 0=not shared 1=shared>,<Priority as integer>;<BIC code>,<Mandate>,<Secondary account number>,<Category>,<Account type as 0=not cash, 1=cash, 2=credit>,<Hide if zero as 0=don’t hide, 1=hide>,<Tags separated with #>,<Issuer with contact ID>,<Calendar with the calendar code>,<Fixing as a number>,<Base instrument with the security code>,<Spread as a number>,<Exclude balance as 0=don't exclude, 1=exclude>,<Shared with all as 0=not shared, 1=shared>, <Shared to all parent portfolio's subportfolios as 0=not shared, 1=shared>, <Decimals for transactions as a number>, <Transaction type code>, <Offset days as an integer>, <Account status as 0=open, 1=closed>, <Account open date in the format yyyy-MM-dd>, <Account close date in the format yyyy-MM-dd>. For example, a list of two accounts: FI12 3456 78,EUR,Euro account,1,0,1,NDEAFIHHXXX,12345678,12345-678,Bank account,1,0,Client account#Status OK,,,,,,,,,,,,0,2017-03-15:234-321,USD,Dollar account,0,1,2,,,,,1,0,Client account#Status OK,,Act/360,0.2,LIBOR,1.5,0,0,0,4,1,2020-05-10,2023-04-09. The account currency (second in the syntax) is validated to be a valid currency in the system. Supported calendar codes: 1/130/360ISDA30/360 PSA30E+/36030E/36030E/360 ISDA30U/36030U/36030U/360 EOMAct/360Act/364Act/365 ActualAct/365.25Act/365FAct/365LAct/366Act/366.375Act/Act AFBAct/Act ICMAAct/Act ISDAAct/Act YearNL/365 You can use *** syntax to add new accounts for the portfolio while keeping the old ones, but this is not required. Without ***, old values are still preserved. For example: ***:<Account>:<Account>). To update the account number of an existing account, use the syntax "[old account no]new account no" in the first field of the account syntax. For example, if you want to update an account number from 1000 to 1010, define the account number in the syntax as [1000]1010. To keep the accounts unchanged, import an empty value in the field. Existing accounts cannot be removed using import.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 20 p.assetManagers No Asset managers Portfolio's asset managers. Contact IDs as a comma-separated list. To import representative tag values, add them after ###. Standalone tags are added as <contact ID>###<tag name>. For example: 04012000##parent.Single-select group tags are added as <contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name>. For example: 04012000##relative-parent.Multi-select group tags are added as a comma-separated list of values: <contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Employee:Finance,Employee:Accounting.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 21 p.fees No Fees List of portfolio fees: <type>=<fee percent>. Types are: transaction, payment, withdrawal, management. E.g. transaction=2.3, management=1.5 You can use *** syntax to add fees to the portfolio and keep the existing ones. For example: ***,payment=3,withdrawal=3.9.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 22 p.startDate No Start date yyyy-MM-dd, portfolio start date

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 23 p.updateDate No Update date yyyy-MM-dd, portfolio update

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 24 p.ruleSet No Posting rule Code of the posting rule set. For multiple posting rule sets, use comma-separated list of posting rule set codes (available from FA 3.12 onward).

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 25 p.extPortfolioIdList No External IDs List of portfolio's external ID's. Use the following syntax <ext_id1=ext_name1>,<ext_id2=ext_name2> etc. If ext_id and ext_name combination for the same portfolio exist just use the existing one, otherwise create new one. If ext_id and ext_name combination exist but for a different portfolio, will show error message.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 26 p.benchmark No Benchmark Benchmark code (configured in the system) or in order to use portfolio specific benchmarks, use the following syntax <yyyy-MM-dd>,<security1 code>=<share1>,<security code2>=<share2>:<yyyy-MM-dd>,<security code3>=<share3> etc. You can use *** syntax to add new entries to the existing benchmark and keep the existing ones.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 27 p.country No Country Country code (configured in the system), if not given will use primary contact's tax country

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 28 p.juridical No Juridical Juridical form code (configured in the system), if not given will use primary contact's juridical form

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 29 p.emailAddresses No Email addresses Comma-separated list of email addresses. E.g. a@fasolutions.com, b@fasolutions.com

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 30 p.reportContacts No Report contacts Comma-separated list of contact IDs

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 31 p.closeMethod No Close method Define as a number: 0 = "Choose" 1 = "No change" 2 = "Depreciation" 3 = "Depreciation and refund" 4 = "Market value"

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 32 p.portfolioGroups No Portfolio groups Portfolio groups the portfolio is in. Specify the portfolio groups as a comma-separated list of group codes. You can use *** to add new groups to the portfolio while keeping the existing ones. For example: ***,<group code>.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 33 p.custody No Custody Contact for the custody (use the Contact ID to identify the custody).

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 34 p.bookEntry No Book entry String value for book entry account

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 35 p.modelPortfolio No Model portfolio Name of the model portfolio (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 36 p.costFormulas No Cost formula Comma-separated list of cost formula codes (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 37 p.tags No Tags "The "Tags" field is a comma-separated list of tags that you can use to categorize your portfolios. To add a tag:  Standalone tags can be added by simply typing the tag name. For example, if you want to add a tag for a Fund and a tag for a ContractOK, you can add them like this: "Fund,ContractOK".Single-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>-<tag name>. For example, if you want to add a tag for an office location in Helsinki, you can add it like this: "office-Helsinki". If a portfolio already has a tag with the same group name, the new tag will replace the old one.Multi-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>, etc. For example, if you want to add tags for stocks and bonds in your Investments group, you can add them like this: "Investments:Stocks,Investments:Bonds". If a portfolio already has tags with the same group name, the new tags will be added to the existing ones. To remove a tag, use the syntax "---" followed by the tag name or tag group name. For example:  To remove a standalone tag for "Fund", you can use "---Fund".To remove a single-select group tag for "office-Helsinki", you can use "---office-Helsinki".To remove multi-select group tags for "Investments:Stocks" and "Investments:Bonds", you can use "---Investments:Stocks,---Investments:Bonds".

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 38 p.priceSource No Price source The method to determine the close market price for the securities in the portfolio. To use the prices from Security's Market data info tab, leave the field empty. To use the first available price from the price fields in the Security's Market data info tab (checking the column values in the order specified above), specify Default. To define a different priority of price source fields, enter a comma-separated list of columns in the order of priority. The values are: Manual, Close 1, Close 2, Close 3, Close 4, Close 5. You can use *** syntax to add new values in the list of price source fields and keep the existing ones. You can use three minuses (for example, ---Close 1) to remove a value.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 39 p.investmentPlan No Investment plan Portfolio-specific investment plan, use the following syntax <yyyy-MM-dd>,<security 1 code>=<share 1>,<security 2 code>=<share 2>:<yyyy-MM-dd>,<security 3 code>=<share 3> etc. If you want to import an investment plan with minimum and maximum shares, use the following syntax <yyyy-MM-dd>,<securityCode1>=<share1#minShare1#maxShare1>,<securityCode2>=<share2#minShare2#maxShare2>;<yyyy-MM-dd>;,<securityCode3>=<share3#minShare3#maxShare3> etc. Min and max shares are validated to align in relation to the target share (i.e. min smaller / max higher or equal to the target). You can use *** syntax to add new entries to the investment plan and keep the existing ones. For example: ***:2019-01-01,NOKIA=25#20#30,AMAZON=15#10#20.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 40 p.profileAttributes No Profile Portfolio-specific profile (configured in the system). Use the following syntax to import / update profile information: <key>=<value>:<type>#<key>=<value>:<type> etc. Note that importing checkbox fields requires you to use the type "boolean" and importing date fields requires you to use the type "date" in the syntax. Profile import allows you to add or modify profile values with a specific key - existing profile values are not replaced / removed unless you specifically include their key within the import syntax. To remove an individual value, use three minuses (---) in the field. If you edit the CSV file in MS Excel, you need to enter an apostrophe in the beginning of the column. For example: '---contact.profiling.totalAssets.To remove an individual value, use three minuses (---) in the field. If you edit the CSV file in MS Excel, you need to enter an apostrophe in the beginning of the column. For example: '---contact.profiling.totalAssets.To remove an individual value, use three minuses (---) in the field. If you edit the CSV file in MS Excel, you need to enter an apostrophe in the beginning of the column. For example: '---contact.profiling.totalAssets.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 41 p.strategy No Strategy Portfolio-specific strategy. Use the following syntax: <yyyy-MM-dd>,<assetTypeCode1#assetGroupCode1>=<share1#minShare1#maxShare1#FIXED>,<assetTypeCode2#assetGroupCode2>=<share2#minShare2#maxShare2>:<yyyy-MM-dd>,<assetTypeCode3#asset & GroupCode3>=<share3#minShare3#maxShare3> etc. For interpolation, specify "INTERPOLATION", calendar code, and two dates before the asset types. For example: INTERPOLATION=SatSun:<yyyy-MM-dd>,<assetTypeCode1#assetGroupCode1>=<share1#minShare1#maxShare1>,<assetTypeCode2#assetGroupCode2>=<share2#minShare2#maxShare2>, etc. For an asset type that is excluded from strategy analysis, specify "EXCLUDED" followed by three dots: <yyyy-MM-dd>,<assetTypeCode1#assetGroupCode1>=EXCLUDED... You can use *** syntax to add new entries to the strategy and keep the existing ones, for example: ***:2019-01-01,ASSET#MOD=100#0#100. If a portfolio has p.strategyFromPortfolio defined, you can’t import a strategy in the p.strategy field.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 42 p.parent No Parent portfolio Comma-separated list of parent portfolios' Portfolio IDs. The imported portfolio will be marked as the sub-portfolio to all the defined parent / main portfolios. You can use *** syntax to add new parent portfolios and keep the existing ones.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 43 p.accruedInterestValuation No Accrued interest Define as a number: 0 = "Transaction date" 1 = "Settlement date" If no value is filled in, the default value 0 "Transaction date" is used.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 44 p.keyFigures No Key figures Define the key figure code and individual observations as date-value pairs as a comma-separated list with the format <code>=<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>:<code>=<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,... For example, AAA=2009-01-01=1.9,2010-01-01=1.10:TAX=2007-01-01=1,2010-01-01=2 You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 45 p.aggregatingSubportfolios No Aggregation of subportfolios Define as a number: 0 = Sum up values1 = Recalculate values

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 46 p.locked No Locked Define as a number: 0 = Not locked (default)1 = Locked

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 47 p.postingsOnParent No Generate postings on parent level Define as a number: 0 = Generate postings on portfolio level1 = Generate postings on parent portfolio level

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 48 p.securityGroups No Security groups Security groups the portfolio is linked to. Specify the security groups as a comma-separated list of group codes. You can use *** to add new groups to the portfolio while keeping the existing ones. For example: ***, <group code>.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 49 p.twrDate No Import TWR date yyyy-MM-dd. The date until which Analytics+ should use precalculated TWR values.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 50 p.limitGroups No Limit groups Limit groups linked to the portfolio. Specify a comma-separated list of limit group codes. Note that you can import either limit groups or single limits in one file, but you can't import both simultaneously. You can use *** to add limit groups to the portfolio while keeping the existing limit groups and single limits. For example: ***,GROUPCODE1,GROUPCODE2.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 51 p.limits No Limits Single limits linked to the portfolio. Specify a comma-separated list of limit codes. Note that you can import either limit groups or single limits in one file, but you can't import both simultaneously. You can use *** to add new single limits to the portfolio while keeping the existing limit groups and single limits. For example: ***,MAX20,EURO40.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 52 p.strategyFromPortfolio No Strategy from portfolio Portfolio ID of the source portfolio to reuse the strategy from. A portfolio can have only one of the p.strategy or p.strategyFromPortfolio defined. Importing the portfolio ID in the p.strategyFromPortfolio field removes the strategy in the p.strategy field, it if exists.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 53 p.pledged No Pledged Define as a number: 0 (or field left empty) = Not pledged1 = Pledged Note that if the portfolio is already pledged, you can't unpledge it via the import functionality (see Pledge and unpledge positions in FA User guide).

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 54 p.closeDate No Close date Portfolio close date. Define in the format yyyy-MM-dd.

ASSET:2013-12-12:FINSTO=50, ASSET:2013-12-12:USSTO=50. title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 49 s.tags No Tags The "Tags" field is a comma-separated list of tags that you can use to categorize your securities. To add a tag: Standalone tags can be added by simply typing the tag name. For example, if you want to add a Fund tag and a New tag, you can add them like this: "Fund,New".Single-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>-<tag name>. For example, if you want to add a tag for an office location in Helsinki, you can add it like this: "office-Helsinki". If a security already has a tag with the same group name, the new tag will replace the old one.Multi-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>, etc. For example, if you want to add tags to your Campaign group, you can add them like this: "Campaign:EarlyBird,Campaign:Friends". If a security already has tags with the same group name, the new tags will be added to the existing ones. To remove a tag, use the syntax "---" followed by the tag name or tag group name. For example: To remove a standalone tag for "Fund", you can use "---Fund".To remove a single-select group tag for "office-Helsinki", you can use "---office-Helsinki".To remove multi-select group tags for "Campaign:EarlyBird" and "Campaign:Friends", you can use "---Campaign:EarlyBird,---Campaign:Friends". For details, see Removing security values with three minuses (---).

Use the following syntax to import / update profile information: <key>=<value>:<type>#<key>=<value>:<type> etc. Note that importing checkbox fields requires you to use the type "boolean" and importing date fields requires you to use the type "date" in the syntax. Profile import allows you to add or modify profile values with a specific key - existing profile values are not replaced / removed unless you specifically include their key within the import syntax. You can use three minuses (---) syntax to remove an attribute value. For example: ---<key>. For details, see Removing security values with three minuses (---).

Define as a number: 1 = Canada, US, France, Germany, Italy, Denmark, Sweden, UK after July 2005 (2,2,3) 2 = South Africa (2,3,4) 3 = UK prior to July 2005 (1,3,NaN) 4 = Finland (1,8, NaN) 0 = Other If you define a reference index convention between 1 - 4, then calculation mode and lags are automatically set according to the selected contention. If 0, then you can use parameters in columns #65, #66, and #67.

body: 68 s.securityExCosts No Ex-ante / Ex-post costs Security-specific Ex-ante / Ex-post costs. Use the syntax <date 1>:<cost category code 1>=<cost percentage as a number>: <cost category code 2>=<cost percentage as a number>:calculationBase=<0 or 1 for the market value to use for the day (optional parameter), where 0 is ingoing market value and 1 is the same day market value>, <date 2>:<cost category code 1>=<cost percentage as a number>:<cost category code 2>=<cost percentage as a number>:calculationBase=<0 or 1 for the market value to use for the day (optional parameter), where 0 is ingoing market value and 1 is the same day market value>. E.g. (without spaces) 01.01.2018: exPostSecCostCat1=0.2: exAnteSecCostCat7=1.3:calculationBase=0, 01.01.2019: exPostSecCostCat3=0.3:calculationBase=0 You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones. For details, see Updating securities. Available cost category codes: Ex-ante costs: exAnteSecCostCat1 = One off charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat2 = On-going charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat3 = Transaction charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat4 = Ancillary service charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat5 = Incidental charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat6 = Other costs 1 (%) exAnteSecCostCat7 = Other costs 2 (%) exAnteSecCostCat8 = Other costs 3 (%) exAnteSecCostCat9 = Other costs 4 (%) exAnteSecCostCat10 = Other costs 5 (%) Ex-post costs: exPostSecCostCat1 = One off charges (%) exPostSecCostCat2 = On-going charges (%) exPostSecCostCat3 = Transaction charges (%) exPostSecCostCat4 = Ancillary service charges (%) exPostSecCostCat5 = Incidental charges (%) exPostSecCostCat6 = Other costs 1 (%) exPostSecCostCat7 = Other costs 2 (%) exPostSecCostCat8 = Other costs 3 (%) exPostSecCostCat9 = Other costs 4 (%) exPostSecCostCat10 = Other costs 5 (%)

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 23 c.representatives No Representatives Comma-separated list of contact IDs representing the contact (for example: 1223,1224,1225). To import tag values for a contact representative, add them after ###: Add standalone tags as <representative's contact ID>###<tag name 1>#<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Standalone1#Standalone2Add single-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name 1>#<group name>-<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Relationship type-AdvisorAdd multi-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>#<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission for trade orders:Make#Permission for trade orders:ModifyTo import multiple types of tags simultaneously, separate the tags with #. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Employee:Finance#Employee:Accounting#Relationship type-Advisor#Standalone1#Standalone2 You can use *** syntax to add new representatives and keep existing ones (for example: ***,04012000###...). For details, see Update contact values. To add representatives to a contact without any existing representatives, add "???," at the beginning of the column's content (for example: ???,04012000####...). If the contact already has representatives, existing representatives will be kept and the new ones are not added. You can use the three minus signs (---) syntax to remove a representative: Standalone tags: <representative's contact ID>###---<tag name>. For example: 111444552###---Standalone1Single-select group tags: <representative's contact ID>###---<tag group name>-<tag name>. For example: 111444552###---Relationship type:Parent.Multi-select group tags: <representative's contact ID>###---<tag group name>:<tag name>. For example: 111444552###---Client portal:Trade.

title: Stub convention
body: Convention Description

title: Stub convention
body: None Explicitly states that there are no stubs. This option is used to indicate that the schedule evenly divides by the frequency, leaving no stubs. For example, 6 months can be exactly divided by a 3 month frequency.

title: Stub convention
body: Short initial Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the start. For example, 8 months with a 3 month frequency would result in a 2 month initial short stub followed by two periods of 3 months.

title: Stub convention
body: Long initial Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the start and combined with the next period, making a total period longer than the standard frequency. For example, 8 months with a 3 month periodic frequency would result in a 5 month initial long stub followed by one period of 3 months.

title: Stub convention
body: Smart initial Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the start. If this results in a stub of less than 7 days, the stub will be combined with the next period. If this results in a stub of 7 days or more, the stub will be retained. This is the equivalent of Long initial up to 7 days and Short initial beyond that. This convention appears to match that used by Bloomberg.

title: Stub convention
body: Short final Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the end. For example, 8 months with a 3 month frequency would result in two periods of 3 months followed by a 2 month final short stub.

title: Stub convention
body: Long final Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the end and combined with the previous period, making a total period longer than the standard frequency. For example, 8 months with a 3 month frequency would result in one period of 3 months followed by a 5 month final long stub.

title: Stub convention
body: Smart final Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the end. If this results in a stub of less than 7 days, the stub will be combined with the next period. If this results in a stub of 7 days or more, the stub will be retained. This is the equivalent of Long final up to 7 days and Short final beyond that. This convention appears to match that used by Bloomberg.

title: Stub convention
body: Both Both ends of the schedule have a stub. Days before the first period start date form the initial stub. Days after the last period end date form the final stub.

title: Business day convention
body: Convention Description

title: Business day convention
body: Following (default) Move to the next valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Modified following (without crossing month end) Move to the next valid business day, unless that is in the next month in which case move to the previous valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Modified following (without crossing mid-month or month end) Move to the next valid business day, unless that is after the 15th of the month OR in the next month in which case move to the previous valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Preceding Move to the previous valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Modified preceding (without crossing month start) Move to the previous valid business day, unless that is in the previous month in which case move to the next valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Nearest For Sunday and Monday, move to the next valid business day, for all other days, move to the previous valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: No adjustment Make no adjustment.

title: What is compared
body: Position information AmountPurchase trade amount in portfolio currencyPurchase trade amount in security currencyMarket trade amount in portfolio currencyMarket trade amount in security currency Portfolio positions and accounts from: List of portfolios matched by name, external ID or book entry.Subportfolios of a portfolio. You can use a subportfolio structure to group portfolios for reconciliation.Part of the portfolio, for example, if the reconciliation file covers only part of the portfolio holdings. Positions and accounts missing in the external data are ignored. For details, see Set up data sources.

title: What is compared
body: Cash account information Account balance. Balances of individual portfolio accounts with the same number are summed up and compared against the balance of the account in the external data source.
